prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The remand decision does not necessarily relate to the potential remand by the Panel of all related actions previously transferred by it. The Panel can consider and order remand of a single action or group of actions if those actions are appropriate for remand. A motion for remand of a single action or group of actions faces the difficult hurdle in that it would result in separate and potentially duplicative proceedings that the statute is intended to obviate. Just as the Panel is generally inclined to order transfer of tag-along actions because transfer is presumptively appropriate once transfer has been ordered, the Panel does not favor separate remand.[1]

Where one action becomes ready for trial, or for some other reason it will not be involved in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings pending in the transferee court, remand may be ordered. In one case the Panel remanded a single action arising from an air crash disaster when the defendant stipulated to liability for damages, leaving only the damage issue for discovery and trial.[2] The panel noted that the common factual discovery and pretrial proceedings related to the liability issue and that the stipulation essentially removed the common issue from the litigation.[3]

The decision to remand a single action that becomes ready for trial is similar to the decision not initially to transfer one action that is ready for trial despite the transfer of other actions to a single court for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[4]
The strongest factor favoring remand of only some of the transferred actions is the suggestion of remand by the transferee court as to some, but not all, of the actions.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Panel treatment of “tag-along” actions is discussed in Chapter 8.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tenerife, Canary Islands on March 27, 1977, 461 F. Supp. 671 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39, 40 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See In re Richardson-Merrell, Inc. Bendectin Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 606 F. Supp. 715, 716 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
